channel.title: RNZ New Zealand Headlines
channel.description: The Latest New Zealand headlines from RNZ News

item.title: Some Auckland students feel 'disadvantaged by lockdown', schools planning catch-up classes
item.description: Schools are thinking about asking some students who are planning to leave at the end of the year to return next year to complete credits.

item.title: Live: Covid-19 updates from New Zealand and the world on 26 August
item.description: Several more pop up Covid-19 testing sites will open in Auckland this afternoon.

item.title: Community testing must continue long-term, GPs warn
item.description: As the government races to test 70,000 people in seven days, GPs are warning it must get community testing back on track long-term.

item.title: Defence Force accused of neglecting sexual violence programme
item.description: Advocates for victims are accusing the Defence Force of a lack of commitment after it left a crucial sexual violence programme leaderless for years.

item.title: Crews to check site of huge Wellington house fire
item.description: Investigators are working out how to access a landmark Wellington house razed in a fire last night to check no one was inside.

item.title: Covid 19: What happened on 25 August
item.description: New Zealand reported seven new cases of Covid-19 today, with the Ministry aiming for 70,000 tests to be completed over the next week.

item.title: Wellington cat Mittens butts up against Covid security
item.description: Wellington's famous cat, Mittens, is facing some Covid-19 restrictions of his own, following multiple attempts to enter an isolation hotel.

item.title: Large house fire in central Wellington
item.description: Fire has torn through a historic Wellington house, with dozens of neighbours evacuated.

item.title: Bus drivers call for security guards for mask enforcement
item.description: Some taxi drivers are also worried about having to confront drunk, belligerent people who jump into their cabs without a mask.

item.title: Northland tourism dries up amid Auckland restrictions
item.description: Northland's towns and tourist spots will remain quiet until Sunday night due to the government's extension of Covid-19 alert level 3 restrictions in Auckland.

item.title: Travellers face losses as STA Travel goes into voluntary administration
item.description: Thousands of travellers who booked trips with STA Travel could find themselves out of pocket, after the company was placed into voluntary administration.

item.title: Rising tensions in Invercargill City Council could lead to intervention
item.description: Invercargill City councillors have been criticised for failing to settle their differences in a letter that may spark government intervention.

item.title: Chief ombudsman finds two mental health units breached United Nations guidelines
item.description: Two of New Zealand's mental health units have been found to be in breach of UN guidelines, but most are functioning well, the chief ombudsman says.

item.title: Covid-19 updates from New Zealand and the world on 25 August
item.description: The Health Minister is urging people to continue to get tested, saying the latest cluster is not completely identified yet.

item.title: Cook Strait's first flight commemorated with re-enactment
item.description: On 25 August 1920, British-born World War I flying ace Captain Euan Dickson took off from Christchurch for the first air crossing of the Cook Strait.

item.title: Mosque attacker's sentencing: 'You have failed completely' victim tells gunman
item.description: Dozens of victims have now recalled the day "the devil" visited their places of worship.

item.title: Baby's death in hot car a tragic accident, coroner finds
item.description: Police are reviewing their investigation into the death of a baby in a hot car in light of a coroner's findings.

item.title: White supremacist Philip Arps arrested for mosque parole breach
item.description: A convicted white supremacist has been arrested for breaching his parole conditions by going near a Christchurch mosque.
